title: Deuteronomy Chapter 29 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Deuteronomy chapter 29 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Deuteronomy Chapter 29 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Deuteronomy Chapter 29.

questions.question: Where did Moses make the covenant with the children of Israel as mentioned in Deuteronomy 29:1?
options: Land of Moab
Mount Sinai
Land of Egypt
City of Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: Land of Moab
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:1 states that the covenant was made in the land of Moab.

questions.question: What did Moses say the Israelites had seen in the land of Egypt according to Deuteronomy 29:2?
options: All that the LORD did before their eyes
Only the plagues
The building of pyramids
The rise of Pharaoh
questions.correctAnswer: All that the LORD did before their eyes
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:2 says that the Israelites had seen all that the LORD did before their eyes in Egypt.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 29:5, how long did the LORD lead the Israelites in the wilderness?
options: Forty years
Twenty years
Ten years
Fifty years
questions.correctAnswer: Forty years
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:5 mentions that the LORD led the Israelites for forty years in the wilderness.

questions.question: What had not worn out during the Israelites' forty years in the wilderness, according to Deuteronomy 29:5?
options: Their clothes and shoes
Their tents and weapons
Their food and water
Their gold and silver
questions.correctAnswer: Their clothes and shoes
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:5 states their clothes and shoes had not worn out during the forty years.

questions.question: Why had the Israelites not eaten bread or drunk wine or strong drink in the wilderness, according to Deuteronomy 29:6?
options: That they might know the LORD their God
Because there was none available
To prepare for battle
To mourn for their sins
questions.correctAnswer: That they might know the LORD their God
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:6 explains it was so the Israelites might know the LORD their God.

questions.question: Who came out against the Israelites to battle when they came to this place, according to Deuteronomy 29:7?
options: Sihon and Og
Pharaoh and Nebuchadnezzar
David and Saul
Haman and Mordecai
questions.correctAnswer: Sihon and Og
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:7 says Sihon king of Heshbon and Og king of Bashan came out against the Israelites.

questions.question: To whom did the Israelites give the land they took from Sihon and Og, according to Deuteronomy 29:8?
options: Reubenites, Gadites, and half the tribe of Manasseh
Judah and Benjamin
Levi and Ephraim
All tribes equally
questions.correctAnswer: Reubenites, Gadites, and half the tribe of Manasseh
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:8 states the land was given as inheritance to these tribes.

questions.question: What does Deuteronomy 29:9 instruct the Israelites to do with the words of the covenant?
options: Keep them and do them
Forget them
Rewrite them
Share them with other nations
questions.correctAnswer: Keep them and do them
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:9 commands the Israelites to keep and do the words of the covenant for prosperity.

questions.question: Who were standing before the LORD according to Deuteronomy 29:10?
options: Captains, elders, officers, and all the men of Israel
Only the priests and Levites
Only Moses and Aaron
The strangers and foreigners
questions.correctAnswer: Captains, elders, officers, and all the men of Israel
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:10 mentions all these groups standing before the LORD.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 29:11, who besides the men of Israel were present at the covenant?
options: Little ones, wives, and strangers in the camp
Only the men of fighting age
The priests alone
The elders only
questions.correctAnswer: Little ones, wives, and strangers in the camp
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:11 includes children, wives, and strangers in the camp among those present.

questions.question: True or False: Deuteronomy 29:14 says the covenant was made only with the people present that day.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:14 states the covenant was not only with those present but also with those not present.

questions.question: True or False: According to Deuteronomy 29:17, the Israelites saw idols made of wood and stone, silver and gold among the nations they passed by.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:17 describes the idols the Israelites saw among the nations.

questions.question: True or False: Deuteronomy 29:20 says the LORD will spare the man who blesses himself in his heart while walking in his own imagination.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:20 says the LORD will not spare that man but will bring his anger and curses upon him.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Deuteronomy 29:29: "The secret things belong unto the LORD our God: but those things which are ______ belong unto us and to our children for ever."
options: revealed
hidden
unknown
forgotten
questions.correctAnswer: revealed
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:29 states that the revealed things belong to us and our children forever.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 29:23, the land described will be like the overthrow of which cities?
options: Sodom, Gomorrah, Admah, and Zeboim
Jerusalem, Bethlehem, Nazareth, and Jericho
Nineveh, Babylon, Tyre, and Sidon
Samaria, Galilee, Capernaum, and Gethsemane
questions.correctAnswer: Sodom, Gomorrah, Admah, and Zeboim
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:23 compares the land to the overthrow of these cities by the LORD's anger.

medium.title: Deuteronomy Chapter 29 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Deuteronomy Chapter 29 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling to trust God during a long trial. Based on Deuteronomy 29, what biblical truth would you share about God's faithfulness?
options: God has faithfully led His people for forty years without their clothes or shoes wearing out
God only helps those who are perfect
God abandons His people in the wilderness
God’s miracles are only for the past, not for today
questions.correctAnswer: God has faithfully led His people for forty years without their clothes or shoes wearing out
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:5-6 shows God's faithful provision and care throughout forty years in the wilderness, illustrating His sustaining power during long trials. This encourages trust in His ongoing faithfulness (Deuteronomy 29:2-3, 29:5-6).

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 29 teach us about the importance of obedience to God’s covenant for personal prosperity?
options: Obedience to the covenant leads to prosperity in all that you do
Prosperity comes only from hard work and not obedience
Covenants have no impact on daily life
Prosperity is guaranteed regardless of obedience
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience to the covenant leads to prosperity in all that you do
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:9 commands the people to keep the words of the covenant and do them so they may prosper, emphasizing obedience as key to blessing (Deuteronomy 29:9, 29:12-13).

questions.question: A believer is facing temptation to turn away from God to worldly idols. What warning from Deuteronomy 29 would you share to encourage perseverance?
options: Turning away leads to the Lord’s anger and curses upon the person
Idols bring blessings and peace
God ignores those who serve other gods
The covenant promises protection despite disobedience
questions.correctAnswer: Turning away leads to the Lord’s anger and curses upon the person
questions.explanation: Verses 18-21 warn that anyone who turns from God to serve other gods will face God’s anger and be separated from Israel, highlighting the serious consequences of unfaithfulness (Deuteronomy 29:18-21, 29:26-28).

questions.question: What does Deuteronomy 29 teach about including all members of the community in covenant commitments?
options: The covenant includes everyone: elders, women, children, and strangers
Only the leaders are part of the covenant
Strangers and children are excluded from God’s promises
Only men of fighting age are included
questions.correctAnswer: The covenant includes everyone: elders, women, children, and strangers
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:10-12 stresses that the covenant is made before God by all Israel, including leaders, children, women, and even strangers, teaching communal responsibility and inclusion (Deuteronomy 29:10-12, 29:14-15).

questions.question: A couple wants to build a strong marriage based on biblical principles. How does the covenant relationship in Deuteronomy 29 encourage faithfulness in family life?
options: Faithfulness to God’s covenant secures God’s presence and blessing on the family
Marriage is unrelated to covenant faithfulness
God’s covenant is only for individuals, not families
Faithfulness to the covenant leads to material wealth only
questions.correctAnswer: Faithfulness to God’s covenant secures God’s presence and blessing on the family
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:13 teaches that God establishes the people as His own and is their God, which includes families, encouraging faithfulness in marriage as part of covenant obedience (Deuteronomy 29:13, 29:12).

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 29 instruct believers about dealing with temptation and avoiding idolatry?
options: By remembering past miracles and God’s judgments against idolaters
By ignoring God's laws
By following the customs of surrounding nations
By trusting idols for protection
questions.correctAnswer: By remembering past miracles and God’s judgments against idolaters
questions.explanation: Verses 2-3 and 16-17 recall God's mighty acts and the abominations of other nations, teaching believers to resist temptation through remembrance of God’s power and judgment (Deuteronomy 29:2-3, 29:16-17).

questions.question: A believer is discouraged and questioning God’s justice during hardships. What biblical truth from Deuteronomy 29 offers hope and understanding?
options: The secret things belong to God, but revealed things guide our obedience
God is unfair and does not care
Suffering means God has abandoned you
Only the righteous suffer
questions.correctAnswer: The secret things belong to God, but revealed things guide our obedience
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:29 teaches that while some things are hidden to God alone, what He has revealed is for us to obey, encouraging trust and obedience despite unanswered questions (Deuteronomy 29:29, 29:20-21).

questions.question: True or False: According to Deuteronomy 29, God’s covenant with Israel was made only with the people present at that time and excludes future generations.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verses 14-15 state the covenant is made not only with those present but also with those who are not present, including future generations, emphasizing the lasting nature of God’s covenant (Deuteronomy 29:14-15, 29:22).

questions.question: True or False: Deuteronomy 29 teaches that God’s anger and curses will come upon those who forsake the covenant and serve other gods.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:20-21 clearly states that the Lord will not spare those who forsake Him and serve other gods, but will bring His anger and curses upon them (Deuteronomy 29:20-21, 29:26-27).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Deuteronomy 29 teaches that God led the Israelites for ______ years in the wilderness, sustaining them without their clothes or shoes wearing out.
options: forty
twenty
ten
fifty
questions.correctAnswer: forty
questions.explanation: Verse 5 states God led Israel for forty years in the wilderness and their clothes and shoes did not wear out, symbolizing His sustaining care (Deuteronomy 29:5, 29:6).

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 29 emphasize the role of community in upholding God’s covenant?
options: All tribes, elders, officers, and even strangers are present and accountable before God
Only priests are responsible for the covenant
The covenant is a private matter
Only kings are involved in the covenant
questions.correctAnswer: All tribes, elders, officers, and even strangers are present and accountable before God
questions.explanation: Verses 10-12 describe the entire community standing before God, showing collective responsibility in covenant faithfulness (Deuteronomy 29:10-12, 29:14-15).

questions.question: A believer is encouraged to share their faith with others. How does Deuteronomy 29 support the idea of testimony across generations?
options: Future generations and strangers will see the consequences of obedience or disobedience
Faith is only for the current generation
God’s works are hidden from future people
Only Israel can witness God’s power
questions.correctAnswer: Future generations and strangers will see the consequences of obedience or disobedience
questions.explanation: Verses 22-24 explain that coming generations and foreigners will observe the blessings or plagues upon the land, underlining the importance of faithful witness (Deuteronomy 29:22-24).

questions.question: What does Deuteronomy 29 teach about the consequences of serving gods unknown to God?
options: God’s anger will bring curses and exile upon the land and its people
Unknown gods grant blessings
There are no consequences for serving other gods
It leads to immediate prosperity
questions.correctAnswer: God’s anger will bring curses and exile upon the land and its people
questions.explanation: Verses 26-28 warn that serving unknown gods provokes God’s anger, resulting in curses and exile, stressing the importance of exclusive loyalty to God (Deuteronomy 29:26-28).

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 29 encourage humility and contentment in the face of God’s revealed mysteries?
options: By accepting that some things belong only to God while we focus on what is revealed
By demanding to know all secrets of God
By ignoring God’s mysteries
By trusting human wisdom over God’s word
questions.correctAnswer: By accepting that some things belong only to God while we focus on what is revealed
questions.explanation: Verse 29 teaches humility by recognizing that secret things belong to God alone, but what He reveals is for our obedience and benefit (Deuteronomy 29:29).

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 29, how does God demonstrate His power to His people?
options: Through signs, great miracles, and leading them faithfully
By giving them wealth without obedience
By letting them conquer nations without His help
By hiding His presence from them
questions.correctAnswer: Through signs, great miracles, and leading them faithfully
questions.explanation: Verses 2-3 and 5 show that God demonstrated His power through miracles in Egypt and faithful guidance in the wilderness (Deuteronomy 29:2-3, 29:5).

questions.question: What practical teaching about integrity at work can be drawn from Deuteronomy 29?
options: Obedience to God’s covenant includes honesty and faithfulness in all daily tasks
Work and integrity are unrelated to the covenant
One may deceive others if it benefits them
God only cares about religious acts
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience to God’s covenant includes honesty and faithfulness in all daily tasks
questions.explanation: Verses 11-12 mention everyone from the woodcutter to the water drawer, implying that covenant faithfulness encompasses integrity and obedience in all work and roles (Deuteronomy 29:11-12).

hard.title: Deuteronomy Chapter 29 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Deuteronomy Chapter 29.

questions.question: What is the main purpose of the covenant Moses is recounting to the Israelites in Deuteronomy 29?
options: To establish Israel as a people unto God and to ensure their obedience
To grant the Israelites eternal wealth and prosperity
To provide detailed laws on sacrifices and offerings
To recount the creation of the world and mankind
questions.correctAnswer: To establish Israel as a people unto God and to ensure their obedience
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:13 explains that the covenant is to establish Israel as a people unto God and to be their God, emphasizing the relationship and obedience aspect.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 29, which kings did Israel defeat as they approached the promised land?
options: Sihon king of Heshbon and Og king of Bashan
Pharaoh king of Egypt and Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon
Saul king of Israel and David king of Judah
Jabin king of Hazor and Adoni-zedek king of Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: Sihon king of Heshbon and Og king of Bashan
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:7 states that Sihon and Og came out against Israel in battle and were defeated, marking Israel's conquest of their lands.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Moses reminds Israel that during their 40 years in the wilderness, their clothes and shoes did not become ______.
options: old
torn
dirty
faded
questions.correctAnswer: old
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:5 highlights the miraculous provision and preservation during the wilderness period, where clothes and shoes did not grow old.

questions.question: What reason does Moses give for Israel not eating bread or drinking wine during the wilderness years?
options: So they would know that the LORD is their God
To keep them weak and dependent
To prepare them for the land of Canaan's diet
As punishment for their disobedience
questions.correctAnswer: So they would know that the LORD is their God
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:6 explains that the absence of bread and wine was to teach Israel that the LORD is their God.

questions.question: Which phrase in Deuteronomy 29 warns against turning away from the LORD to serve the gods of other nations?
options: A root that beareth gall and wormwood
The valley of dry bones
The pillar of cloud by day
The river of living water
questions.correctAnswer: A root that beareth gall and wormwood
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:18 uses the metaphor of a root bearing gall and wormwood to describe those who turn from God to idolatry.

questions.question: True or False: According to Deuteronomy 29, the covenant Moses speaks of is made only with those present at that time.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:14-15 clarifies that the covenant is made not only with those present but also with those not present that day, extending to future generations.

questions.question: What does Moses say will happen to a person who hears the words of the curse and still blesses himself in his heart?
options: The LORD will not spare him and will blot out his name
He will receive forgiveness after repentance
He will prosper despite his sin
He will be given a chance to warn others
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD will not spare him and will blot out his name
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:19-20 explains that the LORD’s anger will smoke against such a person, and his name will be blotted out from under heaven.

questions.question: What literary device is primarily used in Deuteronomy 29:22-24 when describing the land becoming brimstone and salt, like Sodom and Gomorrah?
options: Allusion
Simile
Parable
Metaphor
questions.correctAnswer: Allusion
questions.explanation: The passage alludes to the well-known destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah as a warning and example of divine judgment (Deuteronomy 29:23).

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 29, what is the nature of the 'secret things' versus the 'revealed things'?
options: Secret things belong to the LORD, revealed things belong to us and our children
Secret things are forbidden knowledge, revealed things are laws
Secret things are prophecies, revealed things are history
Secret things belong to the priests, revealed things belong to the people
questions.correctAnswer: Secret things belong to the LORD, revealed things belong to us and our children
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:29 distinguishes between secret things known only to God and revealed things intended for Israel and their descendants.

questions.question: Which phrase best captures the historical context of the covenant in Deuteronomy 29:16-17?
options: Dwelling in Egypt and passing through nations with abominations and idols
Building the Tabernacle and consecrating priests
Receiving manna and quail in the wilderness
Crossing the Red Sea on dry ground
questions.correctAnswer: Dwelling in Egypt and passing through nations with abominations and idols
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:16-17 recounts Israel's history of living in Egypt and encountering idolatrous nations, highlighting the cultural dangers they faced.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'your little ones, your wives, and thy stranger that is in thy camp' in Deuteronomy 29:11?
options: It emphasizes the inclusive nature of the covenant community
It refers to the exemption of these groups from the law
It indicates only men were participants in the covenant
It highlights social hierarchy within Israel
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes the inclusive nature of the covenant community
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:11 includes all members of Israel’s society and foreigners living among them, showing the covenant’s broad scope.

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 29 portray the consequences of forsaking the covenant and worshipping other gods?
options: The land will experience plagues and be overthrown as Sodom was
They will be blessed with wealth if they repent
They will be given a new land to settle
They will become rulers over the nations
questions.correctAnswer: The land will experience plagues and be overthrown as Sodom was
questions.explanation: Verses 22-25 describe how the land will suffer devastation and be compared to Sodom and Gomorrah due to covenant unfaithfulness.

questions.question: True or False: In Deuteronomy 29, Moses claims that the LORD's anger will be kindled against the land because the people served other gods unknown to them.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:26-27 states that the LORD's anger was kindled because the people worshipped other gods whom they did not know.

questions.question: How does the author of Deuteronomy use historical narrative and covenant law together in chapter 29?
options: To remind Israel of their past and urge them to keep the covenant for future prosperity
To present a purely historical account without legal implications
To focus exclusively on legal statutes without historical context
To describe future prophetic visions without reference to the past
questions.correctAnswer: To remind Israel of their past and urge them to keep the covenant for future prosperity
questions.explanation: The chapter intertwines Israel’s history (verses 2-7) with covenant obligations (verses 9-15), emphasizing obedience and consequences.

questions.question: What Hebrew concept is reflected in the phrase 'the words of this covenant, and do them, that ye may prosper' (Deuteronomy 29:9)?
options: Covenantal faithfulness leading to blessing
Predestined fate irrespective of behavior
Sacrificial atonement without obedience
Universal salvation without law
questions.correctAnswer: Covenantal faithfulness leading to blessing
questions.explanation: The verse reflects the Deuteronomic theme that faithfulness to God’s covenant results in prosperity and blessing.

questions.question: What does Deuteronomy 29 imply about the scope of God's covenant in relation to foreigners living among Israel?
options: They are included in the covenant community and its obligations
They are excluded from the covenant entirely
They must leave before the covenant is made
They are only partially subject to the law
questions.correctAnswer: They are included in the covenant community and its obligations
questions.explanation: The inclusion of 'thy stranger that is in thy camp' in verse 11 shows foreigners were part of the covenant relationship and subject to its terms.

theological.title: Deuteronomy Chapter 29 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Deuteronomy Chapter 29 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 29:4, what has the LORD not given to the people up to this day?
options: A heart to perceive, eyes to see, and ears to hear
Strength to fight their enemies
Wealth and prosperity
A king to lead them
questions.correctAnswer: A heart to perceive, eyes to see, and ears to hear
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:4 states that the LORD has not given the people a heart to perceive, eyes to see, and ears to hear to this day. This reflects human spiritual blindness and hardness of heart, themes echoed in Isaiah 6:9-10, Matthew 13:15, Romans 11:8, and Ephesians 4:18.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 40 years Israel wandered in the wilderness as stated in Deuteronomy 29:6?
options: That they might know the LORD their God
To test their physical endurance
To punish them for their sins
To prepare them for war
questions.correctAnswer: That they might know the LORD their God
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:6 explains that during the wilderness wandering, Israel neither ate bread nor drank wine so that they might know the LORD their God. This teaching about God's purpose for trials aligns with Exodus 16:35, Psalm 81:6, John 6:27, and 1 Corinthians 10:13.

questions.question: Who were the kings that came against Israel and were defeated, as recorded in Deuteronomy 29:7?
options: Sihon king of Heshbon and Og king of Bashan
Pharaoh king of Egypt and Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon
Saul king of Israel and David king of Judah
Ahab king of Israel and Jehoshaphat king of Judah
questions.correctAnswer: Sihon king of Heshbon and Og king of Bashan
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:7 recounts that Sihon and Og came out to battle against Israel and were defeated. This reflects God's faithfulness in delivering His people, paralleling Joshua 12:2, Numbers 21:21-35, Psalm 44:3, and Hebrews 11:32-34.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 29:9, what is the condition for Israel to prosper in all they do?
options: Keep the words of the covenant and do them
Offer sacrifices in the temple daily
Increase their military strength
Form alliances with neighboring nations
questions.correctAnswer: Keep the words of the covenant and do them
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:9 commands Israel to keep and do the words of the covenant so they may prosper. This covenantal obedience is foundational for blessing, as taught also in Joshua 1:7-8, Psalm 1:1-3, Jeremiah 7:23, and James 1:25.

questions.question: Who are included in the covenant community standing before the LORD in Deuteronomy 29:10-11?
options: Captains, elders, officers, men, little ones, wives, and strangers
Only the priests and Levites
Only the men of Israel
Only the elders and kings
questions.correctAnswer: Captains, elders, officers, men, little ones, wives, and strangers
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:10-11 describes a comprehensive covenant community including leaders, men, women, children, and even strangers in the camp, showing the inclusivity of God's covenant people. This is echoed in Exodus 12:48, Ruth 2:10, Galatians 3:28, and 1 Peter 2:9.

questions.question: Which patriarchs does God swear the covenant to according to Deuteronomy 29:13?
options: Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob
Noah, Moses, and David
Isaiah, Jeremiah, and Ezekiel
Adam, Seth, and Enosh
questions.correctAnswer: Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:13 affirms the covenant God swore to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, highlighting the continuity of God's promises. This covenantal faithfulness is foundational and referenced in Genesis 12:1-3, Romans 4:16, Galatians 3:16, and Hebrews 6:13.

questions.question: What is warned against in Deuteronomy 29:18 as a root that bears gall and wormwood?
options: A heart turning away to serve the gods of other nations
A failure to offer sacrifices
Idolatry of the golden calf only
Breaking the Sabbath law
questions.correctAnswer: A heart turning away to serve the gods of other nations
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:18 warns that a man, woman, family, or tribe turning away from the LORD to serve other gods is like a root bearing gall and wormwood, symbolizing bitterness and corruption. This judgment on apostasy is consistent with Jeremiah 9:15, Hosea 7:4, Hebrews 3:12, and 2 Timothy 3:13.

questions.question: What consequence does the LORD declare in Deuteronomy 29:20 for those who bless themselves in their heart while walking in their own imagination?
options: The LORD will not spare them and will blot out their name from under heaven
They will become wealthy but miserable
They will be forgiven after repentance
They will be exiled to a foreign land
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD will not spare them and will blot out their name from under heaven
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:20 teaches that those who self-deceive and reject God's covenant will face the LORD's anger and have their name blotted out, signifying divine judgment and loss of covenant identity. Similar themes appear in Exodus 32:33, Psalm 69:28, Matthew 7:23, and Revelation 3:5.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 29:22-23, what will future generations and foreigners say when they see the plagues and desolation of the land?
options: Why has the LORD done this to this land?
How blessed is this land of peace?
Who rules this land with mercy?
Where is the temple of the LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: Why has the LORD done this to this land?
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:22-23 anticipates that future generations and strangers will ask why the LORD's great anger has brought devastation upon the land, highlighting the consequences of covenant unfaithfulness. This question of divine judgment appears in Jeremiah 4:23-28, Ezekiel 36:17-20, Joel 2:20, and Luke 23:30.

questions.question: What reason is given in Deuteronomy 29:25-26 for the LORD's anger and judgment upon the land?
options: They have forsaken the covenant of the LORD God of their fathers
They refused to build the temple
They neglected the festivals
They failed to observe the Sabbath
questions.correctAnswer: They have forsaken the covenant of the LORD God of their fathers
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:25-26 states the LORD's anger arises because the people forsook the covenant made with their ancestors and served other gods. This breach of covenant loyalty leading to judgment is seen also in Judges 2:11-15, 2 Kings 17:13, Hosea 4:6, and Hebrews 8:9.

questions.question: What does Deuteronomy 29:28 say about the LORD's action towards those who break the covenant?
options: The LORD rooted them out of their land in anger and cast them into another land
The LORD gave them prosperity and peace
The LORD punished them with famine only
The LORD forgot their sins
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD rooted them out of their land in anger and cast them into another land
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:28 describes God's judgment by uprooting covenant breakers from their land and exiling them, a theme echoed in 2 Kings 25:21, Jeremiah 29:14, Ezekiel 36:24, and Acts 7:42-43 illustrating exile as divine discipline.

questions.question: What distinction does Deuteronomy 29:29 make about the secret things and the revealed things?
options: Secret things belong to the LORD; revealed things belong to us and our children
Both secret and revealed things belong only to the priests
All things are secret and none are revealed
Revealed things belong only to the king
questions.correctAnswer: Secret things belong to the LORD; revealed things belong to us and our children
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:29 teaches that God's secret purposes are His alone, while His revealed law is given for the people to obey. This principle highlights divine mystery versus human responsibility, reflected also in Isaiah 55:8-9, Romans 11:33, Colossians 1:26, and 1 Corinthians 2:9.

questions.question: What does Deuteronomy 29:1 identify as the setting for the covenant Moses is commanding?
options: In the land of Moab, beside the covenant made in Horeb
At Mount Sinai during the Exodus
In the plains of Jericho before crossing the Jordan
In Egypt before the Exodus
questions.correctAnswer: In the land of Moab, beside the covenant made in Horeb
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:1 sets the covenant in the land of Moab and references the prior covenant at Horeb (Sinai), showing continuity in God's covenantal revelation. This is consistent with Exodus 19:1-8, Deuteronomy 5:2-3, Joshua 24:2, and Hebrews 8:6-7.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 29:16-17, what had Israel witnessed among the nations they passed by?
options: Their abominations and idols of wood, stone, silver, and gold
Their prosperous cities and armies
Their laws and customs of peace
Their priests and prophets
questions.correctAnswer: Their abominations and idols of wood, stone, silver, and gold
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:16-17 reminds Israel that they have seen the idolatry and abominations of other nations, emphasizing the call to avoid such practices. This theme is reinforced in Exodus 20:3-5, 1 Kings 18:21, Psalm 115:4-8, and 1 Corinthians 10:7.

questions.question: What does Deuteronomy 29:12 say is the purpose of entering into covenant with the LORD?
options: To be established as a people unto Himself
To receive immediate riches
To avoid military defeat
To gain political power
questions.correctAnswer: To be established as a people unto Himself
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:12 explains that entering covenant with the LORD establishes Israel as His people, a central theme of election and divine relationship echoed in Exodus 6:7, 1 Samuel 12:22, Isaiah 43:20-21, and 1 Peter 2:9.

questions.question: What does Deuteronomy 29:14-15 teach about who the covenant applies to?
options: Both those present and those not present this day
Only those physically present at the covenant ceremony
Only the priests and Levites
Only the elders and leaders
questions.correctAnswer: Both those present and those not present this day
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:14-15 states the covenant applies not only to those present but also to future generations, showing the covenant's corporate and enduring nature. This principle is reflected in Genesis 17:7, Psalm 105:8-11, Matthew 28:19, and Hebrews 9:15.

questions.question: Deuteronomy 29:5 mentions that after 40 years in the wilderness, what condition were the Israelites' clothes and shoes in?
options: They were not worn out or grown old
They were torn and worn out
They were replaced yearly
They were mended by the priests
questions.correctAnswer: They were not worn out or grown old
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 29:5 states that after 40 years the Israelites' clothes and shoes were not worn out, demonstrating God's supernatural provision. This is consistent with Exodus 16:35, Psalm 121:3-4, Isaiah 40:31, and Matthew 6:25-34.
